newsitem.title: USA: NBC wins Nielsen ratings for May 19-25 week.
newsitem.headline: NBC wins Nielsen ratings for May 19-25 week.

text.p: NBC won top prime time television viewership ratings for the week May 19-25, dislodging CBS, which held the leading spot in the previous two weeks, Nielsen Media Research said Wednesday.

NBC's heavily promoted episode of "Mad About You," in which a baby is born to the husband and wife characters played by Paul Riser and Helen Hunt, garnered 29 rating points and a 17.6 percent share, the most watched prime time TV show during the week, Nielsen said. The show runs on Tuesdays.
The show, plus six other prime-time offerings, gave NBC a 9.4 rating and 17 percent share, it said.

The shows, "NBC Monday Night Movies," featuring the second installment of "The Odyssey," (No. 2), sitcoms "Seinfield," (No. 3), "Frasier," which had two back-to-back episodes (Nos. 5 and 6), "Men Behaving Badly," (No. 7) and "Friends," completed the General Electric Co unit's dominance in Nielsen's top 10 individual ratings for the week.
The performance beat Westinghouse Corp's CBS, which could only muster an 8.4 rating and a 15 percent share. CBS did not have a prime-time show on the week's top 10.
CBS's viewed shows for the week were "CBS Tuesday Movie," (No. 17), "Chicago Hope," (No. 20), "Cosby," (No. 21), "CBS Sunday Movie," (No. 22), "Cybill" (No. 24), and "Touched by an Angel," (No. 25)
ABC, a Walt Disney Co unit, was on third spot, posting a 7.9 rating and a 14 percent share.

The network's sitcom "Home Improvement," "Barbara Walters Presents," in which the famous interviewer chatted with six young stars and golfing phenomenon Tiger Woods, and drama series "NYPD Blue," were No. 4, No. 8, and No. 9, respectively, in the 10 best-watched shows in the week.

News Corp's Fox Network was fourth with a 6.4 rating and 12 percent share; Viacom's UPN was fifth with 3.2 rating and 5 percent share; and Time Warner Inc's Warner Bros. network was sixth, with a 2.4 rating and 4 percent share.
The rating points represent a percentage of homes with televisions and the share represents sets tuned in at a particular time.
Nielsen is a unit of Cognizant Corp a Westport, Conn.,-based company spun off from Dun & Bradstreet Corp last year.
